Posts.Content: Hi, another bit of Sunday good news. My friends organised a Macmillan coffee Morning yesterday, because of my diagnosis, I am so proud of them, they raised Â£500 . Sunny day here as well xx
Posts.Title: More Positive Thoughts This Morning !

Posts.Content: Hello, it is such an emotional time, as well a scoping with the medical side of the illness, having to find a way to understand how, why, what have I done or not done that has caused this to happen to me. Loads of support here and endless information. But, I know I needed help on a more personal level, I was drowning in the news That I had to go through chemo as well as surgery. There are centres around the country that give face to face support, counselling, activities and sometimes the hand to help you through all the pain of the diagnosis. Your sister could ask her bcn if there is a centre near you she could access. I did, and it has helped so much. But this site and all the ladies with experience to share, stories to tell will also help. Someone always has an answer here, no matter how strange, forlorn or even happy your post is. Good luck, to both you, who are doing the most amazing thing a sister could do at this time, and to your sister. X
Posts.Title: In shock, supporting my sister, how can I help?

Posts.Content: Thank you both for replying. Yes, no one would want reoccurrence. I want to try and reduce my chances Of future problems as muc as possible. I am not keen on reconstruction, more surgery, possible More problems and to be honest, at the moment I don't feel it it a priority. But of course that might Change in the future. Probably don't know enough about reconstruction. I think my basic problem Is I have had horrific experiences in hospital in the past and just want to get in and out as quick as possible. Have a mtg with surgeon next week so will have a chat about my concerns before the op the following Week. Really good to have support from ladies who know what it is all like, means a lot. X
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed, less problems than most, but need help with op decision...

Posts.Content: Hello, Thank you for your feedback. Yes, I have been told by Breast care nurse the stats are the same. But for me, I don't want the small chance of another op a week later if not all the cancer removed. I not sure, as I seem to be relatively lucky and it is small, I want to go through radiotherapy unless I really have to. And with a past history of nhs treatment, I am wary Of putting myself through potential hospital care for months. I think I have a viewpoint that might not be the same as many ladies, but I just want as little hassle as possible, for my whole well being. This all sounds pathetic when I write it down, but life can be complicated enough, as I have learnt, so at my age, maybe this is the right decision for me. At least I am fortunate enough to have a decision. I have learnt a lot in a short time about cancer and how it works, how people cope. It is amazing. Thank you all, I go into hospital on 9th sept. I hope tomorrow is a lovely day for everyone x
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed, less problems than most, but need help with op decision...

Posts.Content: Hello, I can see there is a lot of knowledge here, hoping to tap into other ladies experience. MRI has shown 16mm lobular cancer, only in one place, nodes look ok. So, I get an option on what surgery, partial while takes cancer and are around. Or full masectomy Not at all keen of reoccurrence. Don't want breast reconstruction. Want as much peace of mind As possible. Leaning toward mx as I understand less future problems. Handy advice, experience anyone can share would be great. Thanks
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed, less problems than most, but need help with op decision...

Posts.Content: Hi, just had to laugh at RebeccaT comment, thank you for that. I think I will be opting for mastectomy, no reconstruction. Will have a chat with one of the nurses here to check my thoughts are clear on this. There are so many ladies with breast cancer, I didn't realise, it is scary.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed, less problems than most, but need help with op decision...

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, As I am now confused about several essentials, I thought I would ask the ladies that know. Get lymph node clearance results this week, then should start chemo early not, followed by radiotherapy. Can't say I am looking forward to this, but trying to be prepared helps me cope. So, having read various Messages regarding everything from wigs, flu jabs (or being denied, one, unbelievable) to nail problems, I am trying to get my act together, but don't understand all the finer details. Flu jab booked Not sure what to do about wig, bit scary Dentist on my list Can't work out the black nail polish thing, ben never heard of it Oil...what was that for??? What other tips are there to make life and body cope better?? Feel as though I fell asleep and woke up in a strange movie production where my life and body have Disappeared into an alien world, anyway, hopefully drains come out tomorrow, beats moaning About politicians I suppose. Any info would be great
Posts.Title: Lists - what do I need???

Posts.Content: Wow, what do I say, thank you. Bio oil prescription? Need to work out that, bcn probably Enlighten me. Cancer buddy...where do I find one, is that through Macmillan or another Group? Cows udders, well that reminded me of my childhood my grandad had cows And I would have warm milk in a china jug. Didn't realise it might come back to me one day. Have flu jab tomorrow, hav'nt got definite start date for chemo yet, should be early nov. Some things are obviously see how it works, like laxatives and Imodium. Love the frozen pineapple idea. Could do with a tardis right now, and zoom backwards a bit, I suppose it will be better one day. Maybe drains will come out tomorrow, fluids down enough. Need to transfer notes to my diary now and go and find aloe Vera deodorants etc etc xxx
Posts.Title: Lists - what do I need???

Posts.Content: Hello Siani, thank you for all that info. I didn't know about the tooth brush, have to hide my power one For a while. Bit perturbed about the bottle water, I drunk loads of it, not keen on tap water. I guess Fruit juice could be a problem if you get a sore mouth. Need to think about wigs and scarves, don't Fancy just a bald head. Oh dear, can't believe I am discussing this with you. Think I will turn the Relaxation cd on and try and forget it for today. Thank you so much x
Posts.Title: Lists - what do I need???

Posts.Content: That's great news Jan, good luck with the op, do you know when it is yet? X
Posts.Title: Got my biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hello, well trying to be positive isn't working now. Should of had auxiliary node results last week, but path lab problems. Now I get them thurs. I was recently told I would have this treatment, not sure if that Changes if nodes bad news. I feel paralysed and unable to see this procedure as a positive experience. I keep being told go and Get a wig, I know nurses mean well, but a wig is acceptance of my fate. I know everyone reacts Differently, but apart from loosing my hair which is so hard to come to terms with, I can't image I Will be reaction free. I don't feel I can make any decisions, I just keep being told you are having this op, then actually You have to have more surgery. I guess I am terrified of the treatment more than the cancer, maybe Someone can help me sort my thinking out.
Posts.Title: FEC, Taxotere then Letrozole how do you do this?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, After a very steep learning curve during the last few weeks I have surgery on Tues 10th Sept, and Wondered if anyone else will be doing the same, and maybe exchange experiences. I just find it amazing how resilient so many ladies are on this site. The wealth of knowledge and Experience is reassuring when you suddenly find yourself in such a bewildering world. Thank you all for the. Input on this site, obviously I hav'nt read it all, but it helps. Went to a McMillan vintage tea party Sunday, lovely cake! X
Posts.Title: Operation 10 sept - anyone else?

Posts.Content: You are kind. I don't know what a 'tans flap reconstruction' is? I don't want to have recon. I am in early 60s and for a variety of reasons just want the most simple. In and out of hospital. We all come from different lives And experience. I have been busy planting bulbs and moving planes, I guess after the op the drains restrict you along with The post op tiredness. Must get my hair cut tomorrow, having trouble seeing out and unlikely to get it cut in the next few weeks Good night very tired X
Posts.Title: Operation 10 sept - anyone else?

Posts.Content: Hi Karri, sorry I didn't think to include that. Opted for mastectomy, will have sentinel node removal as well. Yes you are right, not at the half way yet in my knowledge of this new world. Feels a bit like someone Has hit me with a large sledge hammer and I am still dizzy from the shock. Thank you for a hug, crying now
Posts.Title: Operation 10 sept - anyone else?

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your responses. It is useful, for me, perhaps not everyone, to learn more of what to expect. I have quite a big problem with hospitals, unfortunately past experiences have left me with post traumatic stress, so Being prepared helps me to cope. Having said that, I am not coping too well at the moment, and again Hearing that others find it difficult, is reassuring to me. I feel I am not alone in feeling apprehensive. I wish I could exist without looking too far ahead Sonia, but I have to consider all possibilities and measure My safety. Ultimately I will have to put my trust in the nhs, and that is a problem for me. Just tell myself it will be ok, all over soon, these people know what they are doing. I am finding it hard to convince myself. I am lucky, caught it early. Chocolate helps. X
Posts.Title: Operation 10 sept - anyone else?

Posts.Content: Hi, I had lymph node clearance Tuesday. Arm bit odd feeling, guess it is post op sensations, doing exercises to help it along. Still have drain in, which is uncomfortable. Had tingles in upper arm, but putting it all down to Op effects, early days for me, hope to feel more sure of the arm once drain comes out. Taking precautions To avoid lymphodema, and just see how the days pan out. I want to get more general exercise as Soon as possible to feel better and prepare for next stage. Chemo, and all that entails. Hope you are doing well though and I will watch for your next posts to compare notes. X
Posts.Title: complete lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: Oh dear, I sound so boring about my lists, AndreaO, I am just so totally lost in this new world I have Found myself in, and besides reading far too much about cancer, and still feeling I know nothing about How this all happens to us, I guess a list is me trying to take some control. Certainly hav'nt got any Control over my life anymore. Anyway, our paths keep crossing, I feel you are a friend!!! !
Posts.Title: complete lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: I went back for my post op results today. Had masectomy and sentinel node op 9 days ago. They have found cancer cells in the nodes. Now I have to have more nodes out in 2 weeks. Then Chemo, then radiotherapy, and meds. Well, that is the plan at the moment. I feel shattered. Reading other people's experience and how you cope is inspiring, but I just feel so devastated. Apparently the lobular cancer is more aggressive than they expected.i am so tired of one problem After another in my life, which sounds self indulgent. I am so fed up with trying.
Posts.Title: I don't know what to say now

Posts.Content: You are all so lovely, just got to go and get a big box of old china to throw at something, I like that idea! Xx
Posts.Title: I don't know what to say now
